TextEquiv.Unicode: a certaine and appointed time abstain
from their usuall maner of eating, but
they restrained not themselves from
sinne and wickednesse, but let their
flesh have the bridle at will, when as
in deede they shoulde have ceassed to
have pampered it, that thereby it be
ing the weaker, the spirite might be:
the stronger to doe and fulfill all sort
of good workes. And therefore, saith
the Lorde: I have not chosen such a
manner of faiting: and the rest as it
foloweth in the 58. chapter of Elaye,
and in the 7. and 8. chapters of Zacha
ries prophecie.
The Apostle Paul verily doth ex
pressly say, that MEate commendeth us
not to God: for neither if wee eate
have wee anie thing the more, neither
if we eate not have we anie thing the
lesse. He therefore doth not fast truely,
which doth abstaine onely at a cer
taine appointed time from certaine
manner of meates, but he which doth
therefore refraine from the pleasures
of the flesh, that thereby hee may make
it subject to the spirit, & do the workes
of faith and charitie, which are accep
table in the sight of the Lord. If there
fore thou doest desire to fast a true
fast, eate, drinke, and sleepe, and take
heede to thy bodie that it waxe not in
solent, fast from all sinne, eate not the
meate of malice, taste not the juncats
of lust and pleasure, and bee not set on
fire with the wine of wantonnesse.
Fast from evill deedes, abstaine from
evill wordes, and refraine thy selfe
from naughtie thoughts. For Basile
also saith: True fasting consisteth in
freenesse from vices, in continencie of
tongue, in suppressing of anger, in
cutting off concupiscence, backbiting,
lying, and perjurie, &c. But even as
the good workes from selves, which
are done by faith, doe not merite the

a certaine and appointed time abstain from their usuall maner of eating, but they restrained not themselves from sinne and wickednesse, but let their flesh have the bridle at will, when as in deede they shoulde have ceassed to have pampered it, that thereby it be ing the weaker, the spirite might be: the stronger to doe and fulfill all sort of good workes. And therefore, saith the Lorde: I have not chosen such a manner of faiting: and the rest as it foloweth in the 58. chapter of Elaye, and in the 7. and 8. chapters of Zacha ries prophecie. The Apostle Paul verily doth ex pressly say, that MEate commendeth us not to God: for neither if wee eate have wee anie thing the more, neither if we eate not have we anie thing the lesse. He therefore doth not fast truely, which doth abstaine onely at a cer taine appointed time from certaine manner of meates, but he which doth therefore refraine from the pleasures of the flesh, that thereby hee may make it subject to the spirit, & do the workes of faith and charitie, which are accep table in the sight of the Lord. If there fore thou doest desire to fast a true fast, eate, drinke, and sleepe, and take heede to thy bodie that it waxe not in solent, fast from all sinne, eate not the meate of malice, taste not the juncats of lust and pleasure, and bee not set on fire with the wine of wantonnesse. Fast from evill deedes, abstaine from evill wordes, and refraine thy selfe from naughtie thoughts. For Basile also saith: True fasting consisteth in freenesse from vices, in continencie of tongue, in suppressing of anger, in cutting off concupiscence, backbiting, lying, and perjurie, &c. But even as the good workes from selves, which are done by faith, doe not merite the
kingdome of heaven (for that glory is
due to the merite of Christ alone) e
ven so fasting, which is an aide and
helpe to good workes, doth not meri
toriously deserve the kingdome of
God.
But now I see a doubtfull disputa
tion arise among the most divines of
this our age, touching the time and
manner of fastings, and also of ye choice
of meates. Some there are which af
firme and upholde the fastes of Lent,
the embring dayes and such other to
be the fastes which God hath appoin
ted. There are that say thou hast not
fasted, if by any meanes thou tast anie
flesh. And their are, which prescribe
and appoint some certaine houres to
fast in. But I for my part see not a
nie such doctrines to bee taught us in
the Scriptures. For the Lord in the
Gospell kept not any of their devised
fasts, when hee fasted fourtie dayes,
but did altogether abstaine from all
kinds of meate, even as Moses and
Helias had also done: wherefore hee
by taht deede of his, did not give us a
ny law to fast so. Moreover the Lorde
in the gospell doeth evidently teach,
that the thing, which entreth in by the
mouth, doth not defile the ma, but that
which issueth out from his heart. To
the pure are all thinges pure. And
Paul saith: I know, and am perswaded
through the Lorde Jesus Christ, that
nothing is common of it selfe, but to
him that thinketh that anie thing is
common, to him is it common. Again,
Let not him which eateth, despise
him which eateth not, nor let him
which eateth not, judge him which
eateth: for him taht eateth the Lorde
hath taken. Moreover the place is e
vident which the same Paul writeth
in the fourth chapter of his Epistle to
Timothie, where hee affirmeth, that

kingdome of heaven (for that glory is due to the merite of Christ alone) e ven so fasting, which is an aide and helpe to good workes, doth not meri toriously deserve the kingdome of God. But now I see a doubtfull disputa tion arise among the most divines of this our age, touching the time and manner of fastings, and also of ye choice of meates. Some there are which af firme and upholde the fastes of Lent, the embring dayes and such other to be the fastes which God hath appoin ted. There are that say thou hast not fasted, if by any meanes thou tast anie flesh. And their are, which prescribe and appoint some certaine houres to fast in. But I for my part see not a nie such doctrines to bee taught us in the Scriptures. For the Lord in the Gospell kept not any of their devised fasts, when hee fasted fourtie dayes, but did altogether abstaine from all kinds of meate, even as Moses and Helias had also done: wherefore hee by taht deede of his, did not give us a ny law to fast so. Moreover the Lorde in the gospell doeth evidently teach, that the thing, which entreth in by the mouth, doth not defile the ma, but that which issueth out from his heart. To the pure are all thinges pure. And Paul saith: I know, and am perswaded through the Lorde Jesus Christ, that nothing is common of it selfe, but to him that thinketh that anie thing is common, to him is it common. Again, Let not him which eateth, despise him which eateth not, nor let him which eateth not, judge him which eateth: for him taht eateth the Lorde hath taken.
